qas.question: When did the British see the need to add anti-aircraft capability?
Where did the New York times report say towers with guns should go?

answers.text: the coasts of the British Isles

qas.question: What was built around naval installations?
Who manned AA guns and searchlights?

context: The British recognised the need for anti-aircraft capability a few weeks before World War I broke out; on <a0_0>8 July 1914<a0_0/>, the New York Times reported that the British government had decided to 'dot <a1_0>the coasts of the British Isles<a1_0/> with a series of towers, each armed with two quick-firing guns of special design,' while 'a <a2_0>complete circle of towers<a2_0/>' was to be built around 'naval installations' and 'at other especially vulnerable points.' By December 1914 the <a3_0>Royal Naval Volunteer Reserve (RNVR)<a3_0/> was manning AA guns and searchlights assembled from various sources at some nine ports. The <a4_0>Royal Garrison Artillery (RGA)<a4_0/> was given responsibility for AA defence in the field, using motorised two-gun sections. The first were formally formed in November 1914. Initially they used QF 1-pounder "pom-pom" (a 37 mm version of the Maxim Gun).
